title: Hyderabadi Cuisine
short_description: A blend of Mughal, Turkish, and Arabic influences with native Telugu traditions, famous for its Dum Biryani.
long_description:
Hyderabadi cuisine is a princely legacy of the Nizams of Hyderabad. It is a perfect amalgamation of North Indian (Mughlai), Turkish, and Arabic influences with the native Telugu culinary traditions of the Deccan plateau. The result is a cuisine that uses the richness of dry fruits and meat from the Mughals but marries it with the sourness (tamarind/lemon) and spiciness of the South.

The crown jewel is the 'Hyderabadi Biryani', distinct for its 'Dum' style of cooking where meat and rice are slow-cooked together in a sealed pot. Another hallmark is the use of unique ingredients like gongura leaves, tamarind, and coconut. The cuisine is also famous for 'Haleem', a slow-cooked stew of meat, lentils, and wheat, primarily consumed during Ramadan.

signature_dishes.name: Haleem
signature_dishes.short_description: A pasty stew made of wheat, barley, meat, lentils and spices, slow-cooked for hours.

signature_dishes.name: Mirchi ka Salan
signature_dishes.short_description: A nutty, tangy, and spicy curry made with large green chilies, peanuts, sesame seeds, and tamarind.

signature_dishes.name: Double ka Meetha
signature_dishes.short_description: Bread pudding dessert made of fried bread slices soaked in hot milk with spices and nuts.

street_food_highlights: Irani Chai & Osmania Biscuit - A cultural staple, savory biscuits with milky tea.
Lukhmi - A flaky savory pastry filled with minced meat.
festival_foods: Ramadan: Haleem fever takes over the city.
best_months_to_visit_for_food: Ramadan month (dates vary) for Haleem; otherwise Winter.
how_to_order_guidelines: One 'Single' Biryani is usually enough for 1 person; 'Family Pack' is for 3-4.
cultural_significance: Food is a symbol of Nizami hospitality (Mehmaan-nawaazi). Sharing a plate of Biryani is a bonding ritual.
